sub_title: Assistant Professor in Scandinavian studies at University of Amsterdam & performance poet
summary: Experienced and flexible Teacher with a demonstrated history of working in academia and the writing and editing industry. Skilled in Swedish, Scandinavian Studies, Dutch as a second language, Linguistics, Academic Writing, and Poetry. Strong education professional with a Ph.D. in Swedish Linguistics from Ghent University.

Gedichten van mij werden o.a. gepubliceerd op De Optimist en drie jaar op rij in de Turing top 100.', 'title': 'Performance poet', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': None, 'name': 'Ling-ON', 'logo': None, 'url': None, 'employees': {'start': None, 'end': None}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Amsterdam Area, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}}, 'company': 'Ling-ON', 'description': 'I teach Dutch as a Second Language to internationals, Swedish, academic writing (at the University of Amsterdam) and I occasionally translate (Swedish to Dutch) and give poetry workshops. You can also catch me performing my poetry on stage all across the Netherlands.  I love to combine my creativity and my academic background (I obtained a PhD in linguistics at the University of Ghent) in my language classes.', 'title': 'Freelance teacher of Dutch as a Second Language (NT2) and Swedish ', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 4815, 'name': 'Ghent University', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C560BAQFWIve9JLlDZQ/company-logo_400_400/0/1583767272648?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=Nv7UOzRLHbYvaaV0e8jOIOqw3PMczh3EAlH9-ISWs2o', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/school/ghent-university/', 'employees': {'start': 5001, 'end': 10000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': None, 'date': {'start': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}}, 'company': 'Ghent University', 'description': 'In my research project, I investigated the development of subordinate clauses in Swedish as a foreign language. In a longitudinal study,  the learners’ use and development of finite subordinate clauses in written texts were analyzed. The learner data were also compared to the usage of subordination by native speakers of Swedish. 

It has been established that word order in Swedish subordinate clauses is typically acquired later than main clause word order (Baten and Håkansson, 2015; Glahn et al., 2001; Hyltenstam, 1977; Norrby and Håkansson, 2007) and it is a notoriously difficult aspect to learn for Second Language (L2) learners of Swedish. Clausal subordination has often been linked to the construct of syntactic complexity in linguistics (see e.g. Newmeyer and Preston, 2014; Sampson et al., 2009; Miestamo et al., 2008; Trotzke and Bayer, 2015; Norris and Ortega, 2009; Lord, 2002; Biber and Gray, 2010). Language with a high frequency of subordinate clauses use is often considered to be more complex or harder to process (Lord,2002). This idea is also dominant in the field of Second Language Acquisition (SLA), which is reflected in the way syntactic complexity is measured. One of the most frequently used measurements for syntactic complexity in SLA is the subordination ratio (Norris and Ortega, 2009). Following earlier criticism on the definition, operationalization, and level of analysis of using the subordination ratio to measure syntactic complexity in SLA (see e.g. Baten and Håkansson, 2015; Bulté and Housen, 2012; Lambert and Kormos, 2014; Norris and Ortega, 2009; Pallotti, 2009, 2014), this dissertation investigates the extent to which it is tenable to consider subordinate clauses as complex, and whether their alleged complexity always implies a difficult acquisition process resulting in late acquisition. 

Besides my research, I taught courses on Swedish language and linguistics.', 'title': 'PhD candidate & teacher', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 4081, 'name': 'University of Amsterdam',
